title: 10 best bralettes for all shapes that are so comfy you won't want to take them off
text:
Whether you want something sexy or supportive, bralettes are the most versatile piece in your lingerie drawer.

If you haven’t jumped on the hype yet, bralettes forgo the wires and thick padding of your usual bra in favour of unlined, laidback styles that are as trendy as they are comfy.

A lot of bralettes have a reputation for suiting only those requiring less support, and while that unfortunately is true in a lot of cases, the industry has seen a boom in versatile, accessible pieces for all sizes.

Once you’ve found your perfect bralette, they’re a lot easier to wear than a normal bra, and can even be adapted into your wardrobe.

Before you forgo your regular bra entirely, we recommend considering a few things about a bralette.

The level of support is an obvious factor, but so is the shape of the design, which is often more adventurous in bralettes than bras. While some people can tolerate lace on their skin all day, others find it irritating and prefer soft cotton.

Finally, if you find that you’re left with indentations on your shoulders from your lingerie, you might want to choose something with adjustable or wider straps. To narrow down your options, we tested the best bralettes on offer right now.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Gap seamless ribbed bralette: £19.95, Gap

Gap’s power lies in wardrobe staples like this seamless bralette. While this kind of design often ends up feeling too tight, it felt gentle on the skin and didn’t cause any awkward chafing. It’s only available in four sizes (extra small to large) so there isn’t much variety, but we found that there was plenty of leeway with each option. Like any seamless bra, you can’t expect too much support, but it provides enough to get you through light activity. If we had to sleep in a bra, this would be it.

Buy now

Tutti Rouge gia bralette: £15, Tutti Rouge

Lingerie brand Tutti Rouge caters to sizes 30DD to 48G, making its collection supportive, comfortable and sexy for people who often struggle to find that rare triple threat in a bralette. We absolutely love the whole collection, but our tester’s favourite was this strappy black bralette. The front straps are purely decorative, adding a nice touch when peeking out of a top, but don’t dig into your chest and are unnoticeable throughout the day. Thinking practically, the main straps are adjustable and the longline shape does a great job of cinching in your waist. Our tester was sceptical at first whether something so pretty could also be supportive, but was pleasantly surprised to not have to make any awkward adjustments throughout the day.

Buy now

Calvin Klein modern cotton bralette: £23, Asos

The Calvin Klein bralette has become something of a cult classic, cropping up in the Insta feeds of Kardashians and Baldwins alike. Aside from its 90s racerback design, it’s soft, comfy and versatile, acting as a bra or top. It comes in four sizes and while we recommend sizing up as they tend to come up quite small, stick to your regular size if you’re looking for the push up effect associated with this kind of style. Despite its sports bra-esque appearance, it’s definitely not one for vigorous activity and those with a fuller bust might prefer something with more support.

Buy now

Victoria’s Secret zebra lace longline bra: £49, Victoria’s Secret

This brand might be known for its extreme push up styles, but Victoria’s Secret has developed an impressive line of bralettes over the past few years. This was our favourite thanks to its simple pattern and ability to support a range of chest sizes. Larger cup sizes are rarely supported by triangle designs, but our tester found that the adjustable straps went a long way in controlling the fit.

Buy now

Lindex velvet bralette: £19.99, Lindex

If you’re looking for comfort, it doesn’t get much softer than velvet. This was one of the prettiest bralettes we tried and is our winner for decorative value. Thinly padded and lace lined, the triangle design works best for those with a smaller cup size, as it doesn’t provide the right level of restriction or support. The straps are quite thin and our tester found that they did dig into her shoulders after extensive wear.

Buy now

Pretty Little Thing black lace cross front detail bralette: £15, Pretty Little Thing

Whether you want to wear it as lingerie or a top, this bralette gives a lot of shape and sits comfortably on your chest. Available in clothing sizes 4-16, it can be tricky to translate from your usual bra size, but our tester found that the 12 was perfect for a 32DDD for reference. You can choose from five colours, but we liked the classic black option the most.

Buy now

Sloggi zero feel top: £30, Figleaves

The name isn’t exaggerating – we genuinely forgot that we were wearing this bralette. Minimalistic, seamless and smooth, it sits invisibly beneath almost any outfit and offers almost as much support as a regular bra. As if the wide straps and longline design aren’t comfortable enough, you can also remove the padding. It might not be the most glamorous entry on the list, but is up there with the most comfortable.

Buy now

Bluebella Nyane soft bra: £28, Bluebella

Bluebella’s lingerie is delicate, beautiful and surprisingly well priced for its quality. The collaboration with social influencer Nyane Lebajoa produced some of the best pieces yet, combining luxurious lace with comfort. The straps are thin without feeling constrictive and it’s not itchy, despite the abundance of lace fringing. While it goes up to a size large, disappointingly this only covers up to cup size D.

Buy now

Savage X Fenty floral lace racerback bralette: £24, Savage X Fenty

When you’re shopping Rihanna’s lingerie brand, you expect nothing short of perfection. Thankfully she delivered, with a stretch lace bralette that’s as pretty as it is comfortable. Lace can be irritating when all over the skin but our tester had no issues wearing this bralette for a whole day. The straps are adjustable, but not radically so, making it potentially a tight squeeze for those with larger shoulders. Sizes go up to XL, which is the equivalent of a 40C, making this one of the most accessible lingerie brands we tried – some additional options on the website cater up to a 44D.

Buy now

Free People rockie bralette: £24, Free People

We were immediately drawn to this bralette’s pattern, but soon fell in love with its comfort. It’s soft enough to wear out or around the house and the V-neck is so deep that it fits nicely under a variety of tops. We did find that it compresses your chest rather than supports it, which can lead to chafing and isn’t ideal for warm weather or larger sizes. It also only comes in two different sizes and while each option is very stretchy, there are obvious limitations for which chest sizes could wear the smallest or largest option.

Buy now

The verdict: Bralettes

For comfort, support and value, we loved Gap’s seamless ribbed bralette. But for those who struggle to find support in anything but a thickly wired bra will love Tutti Rouge’s gia bralette, which was a total game changer for our tester.

IndyBest product reviews are unbiased, independent advice you can trust. On some occasions, we earn revenue if you click the links and buy the products, but we never allow this to bias our coverage. The reviews are compiled through a mix of expert opinion and real-world testing.
